How do you arrange and perform "vocals day"? Seems through the latent writing process along with other issues that I expect occur to reach the perfection of the instrument tracks.But the emotion and inflection is always so perfect as well.I'm thinking of the example "textin' on my iphone" but all your songs would qualify.It seems unfakeable, so how to you keep the emotion present while recording?Or is your process actually pretty quick and painless, so that by vocals you're still just excited from how it's all coming together?

you always want it to be quick and painless, but ever since the technology has been invented to do it as many times as you want, and even piece together, i'm afraid almost zero people on the planet ever have quick and painless experiences any more. one of the very few tricks that does seem to work, if you can do something along the lines of convincing yourself that you have a very short time limit on the recording session. very scary but thrilling, and produces the best results i think. it's just as well, because your voice will wear out if you hammer it for too long on one session. another trick i should mention is try to do it bad

Ive been on a nostalgia trip listening to music I was making 2-4 years ago when I was trying really hard to release my own stuff and then froze and didn't release/finish anything. The thing is, I hear them now with some distance from those crippling perfectionism days where I perhaps didn't have the skillset to close the gap of my taste vs my skill, and I actually enjoy the attempts, but looking back on the process I wish I could do the same things without my mind getting in the way so I can become even better and not have it be such a passionate swirl of good and bad emotions. Ive been trying to figure out what short form of what I was trying to do back then would sound like because I thought I wanted to try something new on my revisiting of music, but hearing those old tracks make me want to try harder this time, and starting small. Im just thankful that I still have those tracks around to experience my journey even though back then I didn't feel  like the y were good enough for me to share because of the expectations I thought people had of me being the guy returning home after going to a great music school. why would you voice something in second inversion, like Bma7/F#, for example? does that all have to do with the chords and voice leading around it? also how would you voice that on keys

it just sounds a little different. you'll have to try it and see. actually i can give you a really common example of where B/F# really is what you want. actually let's switch it to the key of C for easier explaining, and it's not actually Cmaj7/G, this example is C/G, but nonetheless i think you will be able to see the difference. Take the song 'happy birthday to you' in the key of C. right before the end of the song, on the last "birth". the harmony is probably playing C chord, but i think you'll find that the best place for the bass, at this point in the song, is G. i can name a trillion other examples of popular/classic/traditional songs, over the course of the last 300 years, that have had a 1(chord) over 5(bass) absolutely thrive in this right before the end finalistic 'the song's about to end' spot. you've heard it a million times. try putting C over C there instead .... it doesn't quite fit. it sounds like the beginning of the song, .... right before the end ? ... By the way, to complete the example just you you can hear it clearly, the 'good' way to do it, from the final line "birth" is C/G, "day" is D7, "to" is G7sus4, and "you" is C, preferably with the G note left out, just e c , with low C in the bass. and Fmin/Ab was on "hap"

every time i think i'm creating a song or writing a chord progression that came to my mind i end up realizing that it already exists and i was basically transcribing it. how do you deal with it? has this ever happened to you?

(ref: q.php?date=201907232115)7.23.199:15 pm Hey thanks for the response bill, I figured that was the best and tried laying down a temp track, it just felt a little stale compared to the excitement of getting ideas for first time in a while and how good they sounded to me. is this just me being impatient to record and i should wait, or would experimenting with recording the guitar, adjusting it to tempo and then recording a final track of real time guitar?

these are 2 extremely different activities. it makes sense that you would feel lost trying to do a solo singer/songwriter 1 instrument+voc song as a full arrangement, and similarly it makes sense that it might feel impossible to take a full arrangement and perform it live with 1 inst+voc. they are completely different machines. the translation can  be made, but it might take a lot of experience to figure out how the heck it's gonna work. actually what i was explaining before is that they are such different things that i wouldn't recommend trying to get one to work like the other. you might just feel confused and frustrated. in other words, i would say don't try to play the same kind of guitar track. probably don't even use the guitar, or if you use guitar don't use the same one and don't play it in the same way, and definitely don't do that first. i was recommending doing the percussion first. that's just something i've learned from experience. not the drums, not the bass, not the chords, but actually the percussion. like shakers/tambs/hi hats, etc. ch-k-ch-k-ch that sort of thing. this is why you'll need to have your writing all zipped up at this point, tempo and roadmap need to be finalized in order for this approach to really work. if you're curious as to how to learn how to run such a complex operation, i would suggest starting with songs less than 5 seconds in length

I've got some songs I wrote on guitar and I want to record them to record more of my music, but I feel stuck unless I'm playing on my guitar. Is it better to record the guitar and build from there or try to lay a groundwork and then overdub it for stable rhythm?

it's going to be a very different activity, playing/singing as a 1 person live performer (guitar), vs. designing an arrangement. both processes can be very rewarding, but they're totally different. if you're doing an arrangement i would not recommend starting with your normal solo guitar performance. if you're working alone, i would strongly recommend using a click and doing percussion first. then do temp instruments, then temp vocal, then go back and re-build the instrumental arrangement, then finally re-do the vocal, then maybe touch up the instruments then maybe touch up the vocal. where as, on the other hand, if you'd rather capture the solo singer-songwriter/guitar performance, i would suggest capturing as much room noise as you can

hey quick question, if i have a chord with a number, say f11,
that's a weird example which has problems

do i just add the fourthnote in the scale to the major triad? if so what is the difference between an 11 and a 4?
thanks

it's less about rules than you may think. it's like spelling. it's developed over time and there are some exceptions that don't make too much logical sense but that's how it's evolved. i will go through all the numbers and see if i can explain what each one probably means.
 F1 probably a race car
 F2 you might occasionally see this as an abbreviation for Fsus2, that would be notes F G C
 F3 nothing that i know of
 F4 you might occasionally see this as an abbreviation for Fsus4, that would be notes F Bb C
 F5 that would be a "power chord", notes F and C only
 F6 that would be notes F A C and D, optional to leave C out
 F7 that means "F dominant 7" which is notes F A C and Eb. optional to leave out C
 F8 i've never seen this used by anyone else, but i personally use it as a chord symbol for F and F (an octave apart)
 F9 that means "F dominant 9" which is notes F A C Eb and G. optional to leave out C. who knows, maybe even leave out A
 F13 that means "F dominant 13" which is notes F A C Eb and D, with likely also G included, and optionally leave out C. maybe even leave out A
 F10, F12, F14 i've never seen any of those used as chord symbols.
 F11 the reason i consider this a strange example is because i think given the pattern seen with F9 and F13, it seems that any number higher than 7 will mean Fdominant7 plus that extra note. so according to this pattern, F11 would have to include A, Eb, AND Bb. but it is commonly thought (and taught) that Bb is no good on F7 unless you get rid of the A. in which case it would be called F7sus4. However, one time i saw F11 in a book and they actually used it to represent Eb/F (which means Eb, G, Bb, with F in the bass.) in other words, F9sus4. I'm pretty sure if you write F11, it will be not clear whether it includes the A or not. I'm not sure if F11 is assumed to be shorthand for F7sus4. I don't think it's clear enough. If you actually want the A and the Bb, and the Eb, i would recommend saying F7add4. if you don't want the A, i would recommend saying F7sus4. F11 will be ambiguous on the question of whether to include the A, which is kind of an important question

Chords (4 bar lines)

(Intro)

1sus 1 1maj9 1

(Main)

1 3sus 3 6min 5min7 1aug (~ii V I in key of 4)

47 1/3 2min 4/5 b5Â°

2min7 27 5sus 5

(Solo section 8 bar lines)

47 3min7 47 6min9 5add6 (Scales: 4Lyd 3Phr 4Lyd 6min 3Phr)

that generally looks pretty good to me, but the first thing that is definitely wrong is the "47"s, those should be 4maj7. besides that, to just nitpick the notation and not the actual content, when you say "5add6" i'd say it should be 56. (actually when doing it all in numbers like this i prefer to write the 6 higher than the 5, but that's not always so easy in text, especially plaintext like this, so i don't blame you). another thing, when you have the 1aug, i think it's most likely 1aug7. they're not doing us a favor with the release/cutoff of these chords being so long, the chords are bleeding into each other. Makes that flat5 thing much less effective than it could be, and difficult to identify because if we try to pause and isolate that moment by brute force, it's going to have the previous chord smeared in with it. But for sure plain as day to me that feels like a thing i always use, which would be a 3aug triad over b5 bass note. (not b5dim as you called it) so in this key, Baug/C#. if you listen carefully you can very clearly hear the E note (from the C/D chord)   change to Eb during the chord. also, for more even smaller nitpicks, the 2min on the second line is 2min7. just noticed the first chord at the very top also has a 2 in it. so you might say 1sus2,4. and the 1maj9 on the first line i would definitely call that 5/1 (5 over 1). straight off the yacht

hey bill what key is the song Help! by the beatles in? Sounds like Amaj but it has a G chord in it and that isn't in Amaj. If it is A major, where does that G come from?

i would say the intro is Bmin, setting up to seem like it's going to be in D, (hanging on the final A7 sounds like we're about to go to verse in D) but surprise, it's just not. verse is in A. this coasts along comfortably and normally in A, for a while. Then, when it goes "help me if you can i'm feeling down" this is essentually 2 parallel universes running side by side. according to what came before, this sounds like the 2 min chord. so the G will now sound like an interesting flat7. but by the time we hit the E7, all of a sudden you can re-map the entire last 4 bars (two chords worth) as if they have been in Bmin (D) the whole time. similarly showing up at that A7 hang about to put you to bed in D, which again it does not, it just stays in A. just does. to have the fun of going around and doing it all again

Oh boy. I watched a video about chords the other day, and it was really interesting. The video made me realise that I should definitely learn more about music stuff, so I decided to download a free demo version of some random music theory book today. The book thing introduced me to basic music notation stuff first. I was doing fine and having fun until I came across tuplets/grouplets. I just straight up had a short crying session because the darn thing blew my mind (in a negative way). Like, how are you supposed to divide a whole note into three half notes???
write 3 half notes and put a big number 3 above the whole thing
A whole note is worth 4 beats, and a half note is worth 2 beats. 3 times 2 equals 6, not 4!! I'm so confused?!?!
right. the 3 is a cheat. 3 is actually short for 3:2 which means "3 in the time of 2"

I just wanted to have fun!! I've even watched some videos regarding this topic, but I'm still not quite sure if I get the hang of it. I did try to make my own definition, but I think I might need your help with improving it. It basically goes like this: "a tuplet/grouplet is a group o f multip le shorter notes used as a substitute for a single longer note (for example a group of 3 eighth notes can be used instead of a single quarter note)" . Does my definition make any sense? How would you explain tuplets in your own words? What's the most important thing to know about tuplets? Also, where can I find really good examples of tuplets in songs? Thank you a lot in advance!!!

a good way to start is with the most common case: 8th note triplets. 3 of those will fit in the time of 1 quarter note. you distinguish this by putting the number 3 above them like (ref: trip1.png">this (sorry for messy, new computer, no new pen yet. old pen does not work. need a new pen) that's the way it's normally written, but, to be more precise, it's actually 3:2. (3 in the time of 2.) but because that's so common, people just write 3. You can do this with any note value. another common way to see it is like (ref: 16trip.png">this. that's 2 16th note triplets and 2 regular 16th notes. the 2 16th note triplets are occuring at a 3:2 rate which means there's 3 in the time you'd normally have 2. Sometimes you might see a group of 5 16th notes under a number 5, like <a href="5tup.png">this. this doesn't happen too often, but i think you can generally assume that the 5 means 5:4, and those 5 quintuplets are taking the space of 4 16th notes. but you can know for sure by looking at the rest of the bar and seeing how much space they take up. Usually the only time you'll see the : symbol being used is when it's a strange/uncommon situation and you need to clarify the ratio. actually the most common place i think you'd see it is if you are in a 6/8 time signature, which kind of makes normal 8th notes behave like triplets, because there are 3 per beat, with no number 3 written. So if you want to put 4 notes per beat instead, you'd have to say 4:3 to say 4 in the time of 3. like <a href=)4inthetimeof3.png)this. this is exhausting. need a new pen

i remember watching a late night show video where a guest was being interviewed and at some point they quoted a song i think and started singing it in whatever key, and after a few seconds the band joined them in that very key. how does this happen, is there like a player with absolute pitch making some sort of gesture to the rest of the band or does each one start playing very silently until they find the key (i don't remember if there were any wrong notes at the beginning)

even if you don't have absolute pitch, you can get away with it. all you have to do is flick a note, and you'll immediately know what key everything is in. the other players may also do the same, and/or if the keyboard player finds the key they can tell the other players. if all the players know the song, then that's great. if they don't, they can fake it using intuition and try to guess where it's going to go, and/or make ambiguous decisions until they get it. also what is quite common, if the keyboardist knows the song better than the others, they might say numbers or give number symbols with one hand. you may never believe this, but i think all the skills necessary to do this are actually skills that are not particularly common among people with true absolute pitch. absolute pitch may help you find 1 note if you're in handcuffs, but in terms of finding the chords and the rest of the song, it comes down to musicianship/music, which is quite unrelated to absolute pitch

When I begin a project I feel super overly motivated and work super hard but eventually I always burn out, even if I love the project.

I've been working on my current one on and off for a year and I'm forcing myself to finish because I've never finished anything. I would love to see it to completion and I love the project but I can't get myself to work on it. This might be a shot in the dark but any advice?

my standard advice for this is to try doing projects of a smaller size. if you are still having the same symptoms, just try even smaller projects. keep reducing the project size until completion is easily and handily within sight. i think you will find a lot of newfound excitement in actually completing something for once! and you will actually learn a lot very quickly. it's like when you first walk into a new house, you walk through the entire house once. even if you don't do anything in each room yet, just walk through each room. Now you know how big the house is! and you generally know how it goes! very powerful information, will pave the way for bigger ideas in subsequent episodes
